name: Pythagorean Theorem
latex-expression: \forall a,b,c \in \mathbb{R}^+ : a^2 + b^2 = c^2 \iff \text{triangle with sides } a,b,c \text{ is right-angled}
statement: A triangle is right-angled if and only if the square of the length of its hypotenuse is equal to the sum of squares of the lengths of its other two sides.
breakdown: a, b, c are positive real numbers representing side lengths of a triangle. The theorem establishes equivalence between the Pythagorean equation and the right-angledness of the triangle.

name: Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic
latex-expression: \forall n \in \mathbb{N}, n > 1, \exists! p_1, ..., p_k \in \mathbb{P}, e_1, ..., e_k \in \mathbb{N} : n = p_1^{e_1} \cdot ... \cdot p_k^{e_k}
statement: Every integer greater than 1 is either a prime number itself or can be represented as the product of prime numbers in a unique way, up to the order of the factors.
breakdown: n is any natural number greater than 1, p_i are distinct primes, e_i are positive integers. ∃! denotes unique existence, ℕ is the set of natural numbers, ℙ is the set of prime numbers.

name: Euler's Identity
statement: The exponential function evaluated at the product of i (the imaginary unit) and π (pi), plus 1, equals 0.
breakdown: e is Euler's number (≈ 2.71828), i is the imaginary unit (i² = -1), π is the ratio of a circle's circumference to its diameter (≈ 3.14159).

name: Fermat's Last Theorem
latex-expression: \forall n \in \mathbb{N}, n > 2 : \nexists x,y,z \in \mathbb{Z}^+ : x^n + y^n = z^n
statement: For any integer n greater than 2, there are no positive integers x, y, and z that satisfy the equation x^n + y^n = z^n.
breakdown: n is any natural number greater than 2, x, y, z are positive integers. ∄ denotes non-existence, ℕ is the set of natural numbers, ℤ⁺ is the set of positive integers.

name: Central Limit Theorem
statement: Given certain conditions, the arithmetic mean of a sufficiently large number of iterates of independent random variables, each with a well-defined expected value and variance, will be approximately normally distributed, regardless of the underlying distribution.
breakdown: X̄ₙ is the sample mean, μ is the population mean, σ is the population standard deviation, n is the sample size, Φ(x) is the standard normal cumulative distribution function.

name: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
statement: The definite integral of a function's derivative over an interval is equal to the difference of the function's values at the endpoints of the interval.
breakdown: f is a continuous function on [a,b] and f' is its derivative. The theorem establishes the relationship between differentiation and integration.

name: Gödel's Incompleteness Theorems
statement: For any consistent formal system F within which a certain amount of elementary arithmetic can be carried out, there are statements of the language of F which can neither be proved nor disproved in F.
breakdown: Con(T) denotes the consistency of theory T, φ is a statement in the language of T, ⊬ denotes 'does not prove'.

name: Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality
latex-expression: |\langle u, v \rangle|^2 \leq \langle u, u \rangle \cdot \langle v, v \rangle
statement: The absolute value of the inner product of two vectors is less than or equal to the product of their norms.
breakdown: u and v are vectors in an inner product space, ⟨·,·⟩ denotes the inner product.

name: Law of Large Numbers
statement: The average of the results obtained from a large number of trials should be close to the expected value, and will tend to become closer as more trials are performed.
breakdown: X_i are independent and identically distributed random variables with expected value μ. P denotes probability.

name: Quadratic Reciprocity
statement: For any two distinct odd prime numbers p and q, the Legendre symbols (p/q) and (q/p) are equal if and only if at least one of p or q leaves the remainder 1 when divided by 4.
breakdown: (p/q) is the Legendre symbol, p and q are distinct odd primes.

name: Riemann Hypothesis
statement: All non-trivial zeros of the Riemann zeta function have real part equal to 1/2.
breakdown: ζ(s) is the Riemann zeta function, s is a complex number, ℜ(s) denotes the real part of s, n is a natural number.

name: Green's Theorem
latex-expression: \oint_C (L dx + M dy) = \iint_D \left(\frac{\partial M}{\partial x} - \frac{\partial L}{\partial y}\right) dx dy
statement: The line integral of a vector field over a closed simple curve in a plane is equal to the double integral of the vector field's curl over the region enclosed by the curve.
breakdown: C is a positively oriented, piecewise smooth, simple closed curve in a plane, D is the region enclosed by C, L and M are functions of (x,y) with continuous partial derivatives.

name: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra
statement: Every non-constant polynomial with complex coefficients has at least one complex root.
breakdown: P is a polynomial, ℂ[X] is the ring of polynomials with complex coefficients, deg(P) is the degree of P, ℂ is the set of complex numbers.

name: Bayes' Theorem
statement: The probability of an event A given B is equal to the probability of B given A times the probability of A, divided by the probability of B.
breakdown: P(A|B) is the conditional probability of A given B, P(A) and P(B) are the probabilities of A and B respectively.

name: Gauss-Bonnet Theorem
authorship: Carl Friedrich Gauss and Pierre Ossian Bonnet
statement: The integral of the Gaussian curvature over a compact 2-dimensional Riemannian manifold, plus the integral of the geodesic curvature over its boundary, is equal to 2π times the Euler characteristic of the manifold.
breakdown: M is a compact 2D Riemannian manifold, K is the Gaussian curvature, ∂M is the boundary of M, k_g is the geodesic curvature, χ(M) is the Euler characteristic of M.

name: Brouwer Fixed-Point Theorem
latex-expression: \forall f : D^n \to D^n \text{ continuous }, \exists x \in D^n : f(x) = x
statement: Every continuous function from a convex compact subset of a Euclidean space to itself has a fixed point.
breakdown: D^n is the n-dimensional closed unit ball, f is a continuous function, x is a point in D^n.

name: Stokes' Theorem
statement: The surface integral of the curl of a vector field over a surface is equal to the line integral of the vector field around the boundary of the surface.
breakdown: Σ is an oriented surface, ∂Σ is its boundary, F is a vector field, ∇ × F is the curl of F, dΣ is the surface element, dr is the line element.

name: Residue Theorem
statement: The contour integral of a function around a closed curve is equal to 2πi times the sum of residues of the function at the poles enclosed by the curve.
breakdown: C is a positively oriented simple closed contour, f(z) is a function analytic on and inside C except at the poles a_1, ..., a_n, Res(f, a_k) is the residue of f at a_k.

name: Jordan Curve Theorem
latex-expression: \forall C \text{ simple closed curve in } \mathbb{R}^2, \mathbb{R}^2 \setminus C \text{ has exactly two components}
statement: A simple closed curve in the plane divides the plane into exactly two regions: an 'inside' and an 'outside'.
breakdown: C is a simple closed curve in ℝ², ℝ² ∖ C denotes the set of points in the plane not on C.

name: Rolle's Theorem
latex-expression: f:[a,b]\to\mathbb{R} \text{ continuous on } [a,b], \text{ differentiable on } (a,b), f(a)=f(b) \implies \exists c \in (a,b) : f'(c) = 0
statement: If a real-valued function f is continuous on a closed interval [a,b], differentiable on the open interval (a,b), and f(a) = f(b), then there exists a point c in the open interval (a,b) such that f'(c) = 0.
breakdown: f is a function, [a,b] is a closed interval, (a,b) is an open interval, f' is the derivative of f.
